q:
You have an android project with two modules. In one module, you have a code with login functionality. You want to reuse the same code in another module. But, with extending the module option you got an error. So, you need to do it in another way by turning the module into a library. Which of the following option indicates the correct way to do the above task?

Options

1.

Find and module-level "build.gradle" file. 
At the top of file, add libraries{ id 'com.android.module' }. 
Remove the dependencies code in the same file. 
Save the file and click on File, choose Sync Project with Grade Files option.

2.

Find and module-level "build.gradle" file. 
In the file, remove the "applicationId" line and at the top of file,add plugins{ id'com.android.library' }. 
Save the file and click on File, choose Sync Project with Grade Files option.

3.

Right click on the module where you want to reuse code and select "Add library". 
Then choose "Open build.gradle" file and add plugins{ id 'com.android.library } code in the file. Click on save and run "Rebuild" command in build prompt.

4.

Find and module-level "build.gradle" file. 
At the top of file, add libraries{ id 'com.android.module' }. 
Save the file. Right click on module and choose Add Library option by enabling "Advanced options" in the window. 
Click on finish.

There is an android application in which you are using a module called "MyModule". You tried importing it to your project but the module did not find an error in the build window. You need to add the particular module to your project in Android Studio.
Which of the following option indicates the correct way to do the above task?

Options

1.

Click on File>New>New Library.
Select Android Library and click on Next.
Give "MyModule" as library name and search for the icon to select as app icon, then click Finish.

2.

Right click the project and select New Module option. 
It will redirect you to build command prompt. 
Given "Use MyModule" command and then click on Finish to start execution.

3.

Click on File>New>New Module. 
This will redirect you to build.gradle file. 
Under dependeny-build section, enter "MyModule". 
Click on save and Go to Android library window. Click on Finish.

4.

Click on File>New>New Module. 
Then Create New Module window opens. 
Select Android Library and click on Next. 
Give "MyModule" as library name and select a minimum SDK version for code in library, then click Finish.

You are creating an android application where you are using Fragments. Now, your task is to create a class with the name "SampleModel" for sharing data and their host activity between fragments. The code is producing an error by crashing the app.

public class SampleModel extends ItemModel {
 private final MutableData item = new MutableData();
  public void selectItem(Item item) {
  item.setValue(item);}
  public Data getSelectedItem() {
  return item;}
}

Which of the following option indicates the correct code?

Options

1.

public class SampleModel extends ViewModel {
    private final MutableLiveData<Item> item1 = new MutableLiveData<Item>();
    public void selectItem(Item item) {
        item1.setValue(item);}
    public LiveData<Item> getSelectedItem() {
        return item1;
    }
}

2.

public class SampleModel extends ViewModel {
    private final MutableLiveData<Item> item1 = new MutableLiveData<Item>();
    public void selectItem(Item item) {
        item1.set(item); }
    public LiveData<Item> getSelectedItem() {
        return get(item1);
    }
}

3.

public class SampleModel extends ViewModel {
    private final MutableLive<Item> item1 = new MutableLive<Item>();
    public void selectItem(Item item) {
        item1.set(item);}
    public Data<Item> getSelectedItem() {
        return item1;
    }
}

4.

public class SampleModel extends ViewModel {
    private final MutableLiveData<Item> item1 = new MutableLiveData<Item>();
    public void selectItem(Item item) {
        item1.setValue(item);}
    public Data<Item> getSelectedItem() {
        return item;
    }
}

You are creating an android application where you have to create a service with the name "FirstService". In that, you need to write a function for sending messages to start a job and deliver the startID upon each service request. The function should return the key value to restart the request if it gets killed. The code is not working for the given functionality. You need to correct it.

public class HelloService extends Service {
 private ServiceHandler serviceHandler;
 @Override
 public void onCreate(Intent intent, int flags, int startId) {
  Message msg = serviceHandler.obtainMessage();
  msg.arg1 = startId;
  serviceHandler.send(msg);
  return RESTART_REQUEST;
}

Which of the following option indicates the correct code?

Options

1.

public void onStartCommand(Intent intent, int flags, int startId) {
 Message msg = serviceHandler.obtainMessage();
 msg.arg1 = startId;
 serviceHandler.sendMessage(msg);
 return RESTART_REQUEST;
}

2.

public int onStartCommand(Intent intent, int flags, int startId) {
 Message msg = serviceHandler.obtain();
 msg.arg1 = startId;
 serviceHandler.send(msg);
 return START_STICKY;
}

3.

public int onStartCommand(Intent intent, int flags, int startId) {
 Message msg = serviceHandler.obtainMessage();
 msg.arg1 = startId;
 serviceHandler.sendMessage(msg);
 return START_STICKY;
}

4.

public void onCreate(Intent intent, int flags, int startId) {
 Message msg = serviceHandler.obtain();
 msg.arg1 = startId;
 serviceHandler.sendMessage(msg);
 return START_STICKY;
}

In service, you have to create a thread and start it for your android application. You have to make priority of the thread to run in background for handling CPU intensive work for avoiding disruption of UI. But, the given code is incorrect for this functionality.

public void onCreate() {
 Thread thread = new Thread("ServiceStartArguments",
 Process.BACKGROUND);
 thread.create();
}

Which of the following option indicates the correct code?

Options

1.

public void onStart() {
 HandlerThread thread = new HandlerThread("ServiceStartArguments",Process.PRIORITY_BACKGROUND);
 thread.create();
}

2.

public void onCreate() {
 HandlerThread thread = new HandlerThread("ServiceStartArguments", 
 Process.THREAD_PRIORITY_BACKGROUND);
 thread.start();
}

3.

public void onCreate() {
 HandlerThread thread = new HandlerThread("ServiceStartArguments",CPU.PRIORITY_BACKGROUND);
 thread.start();
}

4.

public void onCreate() {
 HandlerThread thread = new HandlerThread("ServiceStartArguments",CPU.THREAD_PRIORITY_BACKGROUND);
 thread.start();
}

Suppose you have used onActivityResult method for connecting two activities using intents. In that, you have to sent result from Child to Parent using RESULT custom values. While printing the result in the execution of app, your parent activity got the result with RESULT_CANCELED value.
Which of the following option could be the correct reason for this value?

Options

  1. Child activity is failed due to crashing
  2. Child activity doesn't extend the fragment class
  3. Child activity should have inbuilt libraries like google maven
  4. Parent activity doesn't have intent library

You need to use a class in your app to interact and know about various services and activities. But the code given is incorrect to do the given process. Which of the following option indicates the correct code to do the given task?

Options

1.

use setContent(R.xml.activity_main) in the MainActivity

2.

use setContentView("activity_main.xml") in the MainActivity

3.

use setContentView(R.layout.activity_main) in the MainActivity

4.

use setContentLayout(R.layout.activity_main) in the MainActivity

In your android application, you have created a structure using XML code with file name "activity_main.xml". You need to set the content of MainActivity to be the layout residing in the given XML file. Which of the following option should be done to get the desired output?

Options

  1. public class NotificationManager extends Object{}
  2. public class ActivityManager extends Object{}
  3. public class ServiceManager extends Object{}
  4. public class ActivityManager extends Notification{}

Consider the given code is written for creating a fragment with the name as "FirstFragment" in the MainActivity but the code is producing an error.

class FirstFragment extends Activity{
 public FirstFragment(){
  super(R.layout.first_fragment);
 }
}

Which of the following option indicates the correct code to do the above task?

Options

1.

class FirstFragment extends Fragment{
 public FirstFragment(){
  super(R.widget.first_fragment);
 }
}

2.

class FirstFragment extends Activity{
 public FirstFragment(){
  super(R.widget.first_fragment);
 }
}

3.

class FirstFragment extends Service{
 public FirstFragment(){
  super(R.layout.first_fragment);
 }
}

4.

class FirstFragment extends Fragment{
 public FirstFragment(){
  super(R.layout.first_fragment);
 }
}

You want to add a new service as a child to the application element in the manifest file for declaring service say "NewService". But, the given code is incorrect for creating a service.

<manifest ... >
  <application ... >
      <service android:servicename="NewService" />
      ...
  </application ... >
  ...
</manifest >

Find the correct code snippet for achieving the desired result.

Options

1.

<manifest ... >
  <application ... >
      <service android:service=".NewService" />
      ...
  </application ... >
  ...
</manifest >

2.

<manifest ... >
  <application ... >
      <service android:title=".NewService" />
      ...
  </application ... >
  ...
</manifest >

3.

<manifest ... >
  <application ... >
      <service android:name=".NewService" />
      ...
  </application ... >
  ...
</manifest >

4.

<manifest ... >
  <application ... >
      <service android="NewService" />
      ...
  </application ... >
  ...
</manifest >

You have used the given code in your android application for creating an object. This should specify the input to be collected from the user which will be passed along with intent that will be sent inside PendingIntent. But the code is not enabling the required functionality.

public class InputIntent extends Object implements ActivityManager{}

Which of the following option indicates the correct class to do the above task?

Options

  1. public class RemoteInput extends Activity implements Parcelable{}
  2. public class InputIntent extends Object implements Parcelable{}
  3. public class RemoteInput extends Object implements Parcelable{}
  4. public class InputIntent extends Activity implements ActivityManager{}

Suppose you have a Linear Layout that has two buttons with vertical orientation. The XML code is given here. Now, you should make navigation focus to cycle from top to bottom or vice versa. The code is not doing it automatically.

<LinearLayout android:orientation="vertical">
<Button android:id="@+id/top" … /> 
<Button android:id="@+id/bottom" … />
</LinearLayout>

Find the correct code snippet for achieving the desired result. 

Options

1.

<LinearLayout
 android:orientation="vertical">
 <Button android:id="@+id/top"
 android:cycleNext="@+id/bottom"
 … />
 <Button android:id="@+id/bottom"
 android:cycleNext="@+id/top"
 … />
</LinearLayout>

2.

<LinearLayout
 android:orientation="vertical">
 <Button android:id="@+id/top"
 android:nextFocus="@+id/bottom"
 … />
 <Button android:id="@+id/bottom"
 android:nextFocus="@+id/top"
 … />
</LinearLayout>

 3.

<LinearLayout
 android:orientation="vertical">
 <Button android:id="@+id/top"
 android:nextFocusTop="@+id/bottom"
 … />
 <Button android:id="@+id/bottom"
 android:nextFocusBottom="@+id/top"
 … />
</LinearLayout>

4.

<LinearLayout
 android:orientation="vertical">
 <Button android:id="@+id/top"
 android:nextFocusUp="@+id/bottom"
 … />
 <Button android:id="@+id/bottom"
 android:nextFocusDown="@+id/top"
 … />
</LinearLayout>

You need to set up the environment for using Fragments in your android application. For this, you have to add dependency on AndroidX Fragment library. You have entered the given code in build.gradle file for doing the above functionality. But, got an error.

 buildscript{ … 
repositories{ 
maven() ... } }
 allprojects{ 
repositories{ 
maven() ... } }

Which of the following option indicates adding the required dependency?

Options

1.

buildscript{ …
 repositories{
 google()...}}
allprojects{
 repositories{
 google() ...}}

2.

buildscript{…
 repositories{
 java()...}}
allprojects{
 repositories{
 java()...}}

3.

buildscript{…
 repositories{
 microsoft()...}}
allprojects{
 repositories{
 microsoft()...}}

4.

buildscript{…
 repositories{
 fragment()...}}
allprojects{
 repositories{
 fragment() ...}}

You are using an event handler in your android application. The provided handler is called when a key up the event occurs but it should be called when a new key event occurs.

public boolean onKeyUp(int keyCode, KeyEvent event){}

Which of the following method will give the desired functionality?

Options

  1. public boolean onKeyLongPress(int keyCode, KeyEvent event){}
  2. public boolean onKeyDown(int keyCode, KeyEvent event){}
  3. public boolean onKeyMultiple(int keyCode, KeyEvent event){}
  4. public boolean onKeyPreIme(int keyCode, KeyEvent event){}

You want to implement an event listener in an android application which will be triggered upon the user touching or clicking on a button widget. The code given is wrong for the above functionality. Assume button as b1.

b1.setOnFocusChangeListener(new View.OnFocusChangeListener() {
 public void onFocusChange(View v){}}

Find the correct code snippet for achieving the desired result.

Options

1.

b1.setOnClickListener(new View.OnClickListener() {
    public void onClick(View v){}}

2.

b1.setOnFocusChangeListener(new View.OnFocusChangeListener() {
 public void onKey(View v){}}

3.

b1.setOnTouchListener(new View.OnTouchListener() {
 public void onTouch(View v){}}

4.

b1.setOnButtonListener(new View.OnButtonListener() {
  public void onButton(View v){}}

You want to declare a new activity with the name "SampleActivity". This should be declared in the Manifest file for configuration. Find the correct code snippet for achieving the desired result.

4.

What functionality does the given code will be provided as output?

<activity android:name="ShareActivity" android:exported="false">
    <intent-filter>
        <action android:name="android.intent.action.SEND"/>
        <category android:name="android.intent.category.DEFAULT"/>
        <data android:mimeType="text/plain"/>
    </intent-filter>
</activity>

Options

  1. Activity declaration with an intent filter to receive an ACTION_SEND_VIEW intent when the data type is mime
  2. Activity declaration with an intent filter to receive an ACTION_SEND intent when the data type is text
  3. Activity declaration with an intent filter to receive an ACTION_SEND intent when the data type is mime
  4. Activity declaration with an intent filter to receive an SHARE_ACTIVITY intent when the data type is text

Suppose you have two activities Main and Second. There is a button in Main that will call SecondActivity for sending the result from MainActivity using Intent and send back the result to Main using Activity.RESULT_OK method. Now, your task is to print the value in MainActivity using editText control with id "get", which we get from SecondActivity. The code provided is incorrect for desired functionality.

protected void onActivityResult(int requestCode, int resultCode,Intent d){
 tv=(EditText)findViewById(R.id.get);
 if(request==0||result==Activity.RESULT_OK){
  String result=d.getStringExtra("result");
  tv.setText(result);
 }
}

Which of the following option represents the correct MainActivity code to get desired output?

Options

1.

tv=(EditText)findViewById(R.id);
if(requestCode==0){
 String result=d.getStringExtra("result");
 tv.setText(result);
}super.onActivityResult(requestCode,d);

2.

tv=(EditText)findViewById(R.id.get);
if(requestCode==1&&resultCode==Activity.RESULT_OK){
 String result=d.getStringExtra("result");
 tv.setText(result);}
super.onActivityResult(requestCode,resultCode,d);

3.

tv=(EditText)findViewById(R.id.getttt);
if(request==1||result==Activity.RESULT_OK){
 String result=d.getStringExtra("result");
 tv.setText(result);}
super.onActivityResult(request,result,d);

4.

tv=(EditText)findViewById(R.id.getttt);
if(requestCode==1||resultCode==Activity.RESULT_OK){
 String result=d.getStringExtra("result");
 tv.setText(result);}
super.onActivityResult(requestCode,resultCode,d);

You were asked to write code for an android application that has a relative layout with a text view control in it. The message should be shown as "Hello" and should be in blue color with a font size of 20dp. But, the code is showing a blank screen.

 android:textmessage="hello"
 android:color="@android:color/blue"
 android:fontsize="20dp" />

Which of the following option represents the correct XML code?

Options

1.

<TextView
   android:text="hello"
   android:textColor="@android:color/blue"
   android:textSize="20dp" />

2.

<TextView
   android:textMessage="hello"
   android:textColor="@android:color/blue"
   android:font="20dp" />

3.

<TextView
   android:text="hello"
   android:color="@android:color/blue"
   android:textSize="20dp" />

4.

<TextView
   android:textMessage="hello"
   android:color="@android:color/blue"
   android:font="20dp" />

You need to use a Linear layout for an android application. You should consider the orientation of the layout as vertical but this XML code is not producing the desired result.

<android:layout_orientation="1" >

Which of the following option represents the correct XML code?

Options

1.

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<LinearLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
  android:layout_orientation="vertical" >
</LinearLayout>

2.

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<LinearLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
  android:orientation="1" >
</LinearLayout>

3.

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<LinearLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
  android:orientation="vertical" >
</LinearLayout>

4.

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<LinearLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
  orientation="vertical" >
</LinearLayout>

You were given a code of an android application. You need to use a Linear layout with width and height should be equal to the parent. But, the given XML code is not giving the actual result.

<android_width="fill_parent"
android_height="fill_parent" >

Which of the following option represents the correct XML code?

Options

1.

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<LinearLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
  android:layout_width="wrap_parent"
  android:layout_height="wrap_parent" >
</LinearLayout>

2.

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<LinearLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
  android:layout_width="fill_parent"
  android:layout_height="fill_parent" >
</LinearLayout>

3.

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<LinearLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
  android_width="wrap_parent"
  android_height="wrap_parent" >
</LinearLayout>

4.

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<LinearLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
  width="fill_parent"
  height="fill_parent" >
</LinearLayout>

In Android, you are working on Data Binding Library, to build a widget. It's a widget that changes dynamically, displaying weather. Based on your knowledge and situation working on Data Binding Library which of the following statements would you conclude as correct?

 

Statements:

  1.  The Data Binding Library allows you to bind UI components in your layouts to data sources in your app.
     
  2. The following code assigns text to the widget directly in the layout file- 
    <TextView android:text="@{viewmodel.userName}" />

     

  3. The Data Binding Library binds UI components at runtime.

You are working on a student portal application using  Android and you have a student database. Now if you are using SQLite as the database management system then which of the following Android architectures can you use to work with the student database in your app?

 

Architecture:

  1. ViewModel
     
  2. Room
     
  3. Data Binding
     
  4. Paging

You are working on an Android application and you have created a service that plays music in the background. Now if the service has implemented the method onStartCommand() then which of the following statements is correct?

 

Statements:

  1. The flags parameter in the onStartCommand() method can have 0 as its value.
     
  2. The onStartCommand() method is called by the system on the service's main thread.
     
  3. You can call the stopService() method to stop the application service.

In Android, a fragment represents a reusable portion of an app's UI. It defines and manages its own layout, has its own lifecycle, and can handle its own input events. Now, which of the following statements is correct about Fragments?

 

Statements:

  1. A fragment can be dependent on a specific parent activity or fragment.
     
  2. The maximum state of a fragment is determined by the FragmentManager.
     
  3. The onAttach() method is called only once in a fragment life cycle.

You are working on an Android messaging application. And you want to add the functionality in the app to share media files. Now, in order to add the functionality in the app, you are using Android Intents. Which of the following statements is correct about Intents? 

 

Statements:

  1. Intents are used to pass data and initiate actions with apps and components.
     
  2. The class Intent implements the Cloneable interface of java.lang package.
     
  3. The implicit intents do not have a specified component with them.

Alice was working on filtering operations in Android. Alice wants to terminate the previous non-executed filtering requests and wants to create a new filtering request. So she executed the following commands from java.lang.Object package. Which of the following statements about the commands is true?

 

Statements:

  1. The filter class is an abstract class.
     
  2. Calling the following method performs filtering operations asynchronously- 
    public final void filter (CharSequence constraint)

     

  3. The following method starts a synchronous filtering operation-

    public final void filter (CharSequence constraint, Filter.FilterListener listener)

Bob was looking at his mark sheet and got an idea to represent his marks in a graphical way. As he was familiar with Android he used the ProgressBar UI Control. Which of the following statements about the ProgressBar UI control is true?

 

Statements:

  1. The class ProgressBar inherits the properties of the class View
     
  2. The indeterminate mode of ProgressBar is used when the duration of an operation is not known.
     
  3. The indeterminate mode is the default mode in ProgressBar

Ben was developing a game where the player should tap the bubbles and then the bubbles will explode. So he developed the game using the Event Listeners in Android. Which of the following statements about the Event Listeners methods is true?

 

Statements:

  1. The onLongClick() method returns a boolean value.
     
  2. The onClick() method does not return any value.
     
  3. The onFocusChanged() method returns a boolean value.
     
  4. The onFocusChanged() method is marked by a protected access specifier.

Mike was developing a home page for his hostel website. So to make it more diverse in colours, he added a feature to customise the colour of the home where context remains the same. He added a button to automatically switch colour randomly. So to develop this which of the following XML attributes of the class Transition did he used?

 

XML attributes

  1. android: duration
     
  2. android: endDelay
     
  3. android: Interpolator

The Android SDK Command-Line Tools package contains various tools for building and debugging Android apps. Now you have the latest version of SDK command-line tools installed. If you are required to use the previous version of the command-line tools package then which of the following commands will you use if you are updating the command-line tools package through SDK Manager and you have selected your update channel as Beta?

 

Commands:

  1. sdkmanager 'cmdline-tools;latest' --channel=1

     

  2. sdkmanager 'cmdline-tools;latest' --channel=3

Anita is developing an Android application for food delivery from various restaurants. She wants to make UI more interactive. While the user tries to sign in or signup for the application, she wanted to include a transition effect in such a way that when the user clicks on the Login button, the window fades off and navigates to the next window. For this, she wants to explore more about its XML attributes. She had designed the following statements about the transition effects from her learning process. Try to help her by picking out the correct statements regarding these XML attributes:

Statements

  1. The XML attribute android.duration represents the amount of time (in milliseconds) that the transition should run. 

  2. The XML attribute android.delay represents the delay in milliseconds before the transition starts. 

  3. The XML attribute android.interpolator represents an interpolator to be used in the animations spawned by this transition.
In Android, which of the following tools is used to create a structure for writing code?

What is the output of the following Android code:

public class MainActivity extends ListActivity {

public static final String MyPREFERENCES = "MyPrefs" ;
....

     .....

Which of the following cursors tracks the changes made in any URI?

In Android, which of the following encodings does not have a byte order application?

a.option: Getting their Linux user Id and VM

In Android, which of the following properties will be used to reduce the speech volume?

Which of these is the switch statement in the following Android code:

	 public class sendSMS extends Activity {
     private void sendSMS(... , ...) {

	String SENT = "SMS_SENT";
	String DELIVERED = "SMS_DELIVERED";
     ....
	PendingIntent deliveredPI = PendingIntent.getBroadcast(this, 0,
	new Intent(DELIVERED), 0);
.....
registerReceiver(new BroadcastReceiver() {
		@Override
		public void onReceive(Context arg0, Intent arg1) {
			
	switch (....) {

	case Activity.RESULT_OK:
		Toast.makeText(getBaseContext(), "SMS delivered",
		Toast.LENGTH_SHORT).show();
		break;
	case Activity.RESULT_CANCELED:
		Toast.makeText(getBaseContext(), "SMS not delivered",
		Toast.LENGTH_SHORT).show();
		break;
	}
		}
	}, new IntentFilter(DELIVERED));

	SmsManager sms = SmsManager.getDefault();
....

}

What is the output of the following Android code:

	      public class MainActivity extends ListActivity 
{  	      
         TextView dataView;  	  
	    @Override  
	    protected void onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) {  
	        super.onCreate(savedInstanceState);  
	        setContentView(R.layout.activity_main);  
	        ....
	        dataView = (TextView) findViewById(R.id.dataTextView);  
	  
	    }

What is the output of the following Android code:



 public class WallpaperChangeService extends Service implements Runnable {
	
	private int wallpaperId[] = {... };
	private int FLAG=0;	
	private Thread t;

	
	private Bitmap bitmap;
	private Bitmap bitmap1;

	
	@Override
	public int onStartCommand(Intent intent, int flag,int startId)
	{
       ....
	bitmap= BitmapFactory.decodeResource(getResources(),wallpaperId[0]);
	bitmap1= BitmapFactory.decodeResource(getResources(),wallpaperId[1]);
	t = new Thread(WallpaperChangeService.this);
	t.start();
	...
	}

	@Override
	public void run() {

		try {
		while(true){
	if(FLAG==0)	{			
				this.setWallpaper(bitmap);			
				FLAG++;				
			}
	else{	
				this.setWallpaper(bitmap1);
				FLAG++;
	}				
	Thread.sleep(3000);
	}
		
	}
	catch (Exception e){
		e.printStackTrace();
	}
	}

}

public class LeaksActivity extends Activity implements LocationListener {

    private LocationManager locationManager;

    @Override
    protected void onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) {
      super.onCreate(savedInstanceState);
       setContentView(....);
   locationManager = (LocationManager) getSystemService(LOCATION_SERVICE);

   locationManager.requestLocationUpdates(LocationManager.NETWORK_PROVIDER,                
    TimeUnit.MINUTES.toMillis(5), 100, this);
    /*Line A*/
    }

    @Override
    protected void onDestroy() {
        super.onDestroy();
        /*Line B*/
    }

    // Listener implementation omitted
}
